text: THE BLACK TULIP
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: By Alexandre Dumas (Pere)
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Chapter 1. A Grateful People
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: On the 20th of August, 1672, the city of the Hague, always so lively,
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: so neat, and so trim that one might believe every day to be Sunday, with
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: its shady park, with its tall trees, spreading over its Gothic houses,
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: with its canals like large mirrors, in which its steeples and its almost
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Eastern cupolas are reflected,--the city of the Hague, the capital of
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: the Seven United Provinces, was swelling in all its arteries with a
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: black and red stream of hurried, panting, and restless citizens, who,
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: with their knives in their girdles, muskets on their shoulders, or
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: sticks in their hands, were pushing on to the Buytenhof, a terrible
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: prison, the grated windows of which are still shown, where, on the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: charge of attempted murder preferred against him by the surgeon
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Tyckelaer, Cornelius de Witt, the brother of the Grand Pensionary of
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Holland was confined.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: If the history of that time, and especially that of the year in the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: middle of which our narrative commences, were not indissolubly connected
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: with the two names just mentioned, the few explanatory pages which we
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: are about to add might appear quite supererogatory; but we will, from
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: the very first, apprise the reader--our old friend, to whom we are wont
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: on the first page to promise amusement, and with whom we always try to
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: keep our word as well as is in our power--that this explanation is as
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: indispensable to the right understanding of our story as to that of the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: great event itself on which it is based.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Cornelius de Witt, Ruart de Pulten, that is to say, warden of the dikes,
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: ex-burgomaster of Dort, his native town, and member of the Assembly
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: of the States of Holland, was forty-nine years of age, when the Dutch
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: people, tired of the Republic such as John de Witt, the Grand Pensionary
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: of Holland, understood it, at once conceived a most violent affection
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: for the Stadtholderate, which had been abolished for ever in Holland by
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: the "Perpetual Edict" forced by John de Witt upon the United Provinces.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: As it rarely happens that public opinion, in its whimsical flights,
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: does not identify a principle with a man, thus the people saw the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: personification of the Republic in the two stern figures of the brothers
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: De Witt, those Romans of Holland, spurning to pander to the fancies
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: of the mob, and wedding themselves with unbending fidelity to liberty
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: without licentiousness, and prosperity without the waste of superfluity;
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: on the other hand, the Stadtholderate recalled to the popular mind the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: grave and thoughtful image of the young Prince William of Orange.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: The brothers De Witt humoured Louis XIV., whose moral influence was felt
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: by the whole of Europe, and the pressure of whose material power Holland
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: had been made to feel in that marvellous campaign on the Rhine, which,
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: in the space of three months, had laid the power of the United Provinces
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: prostrate.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Louis XIV. had long been the enemy of the Dutch, who insulted or
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: ridiculed him to their hearts' content, although it must be said that
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: they generally used French refugees for the mouthpiece of their spite.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Their national pride held him up as the Mithridates of the Republic.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: The brothers De Witt, therefore, had to strive against a double
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: difficulty,--against the force of national antipathy, and, besides,
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: against the feeling of weariness which is natural to all vanquished
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: people, when they hope that a new chief will be able to save them from
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: ruin and shame.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: This new chief, quite ready to appear on the political stage, and to
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: measure himself against Louis XIV., however gigantic the fortunes of the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Grand Monarch loomed in the future, was William, Prince of Orange, son
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: of William II., and grandson, by his mother Henrietta Stuart, of Charles
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: I. of England. We have mentioned him before as the person by whom the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: people expected to see the office of Stadtholder restored.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: This young man was, in 1672, twenty-two years of age. John de Witt, who
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: was his tutor, had brought him up with the view of making him a good
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: citizen. Loving his country better than he did his disciple, the master
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: had, by the Perpetual Edict, extinguished the hope which the young
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Prince might have entertained of one day becoming Stadtholder. But God
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: laughs at the presumption of man, who wants to raise and prostrate the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: powers on earth without consulting the King above; and the fickleness
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: and caprice of the Dutch combined with the terror inspired by Louis
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: XIV., in repealing the Perpetual Edict, and re-establishing the office
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: of Stadtholder in favour of William of Orange, for whom the hand of
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Providence had traced out ulterior destinies on the hidden map of the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: future.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: The Grand Pensionary bowed before the will of his fellow citizens;
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Cornelius de Witt, however, was more obstinate, and notwithstanding all
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: the threats of death from the Orangist rabble, who besieged him in his
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: house at Dort, he stoutly refused to sign the act by which the office of
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Stadtholder was restored. Moved by the tears and entreaties of his wife,
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: he at last complied, only adding to his signature the two letters V. C.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: (Vi Coactus), notifying thereby that he only yielded to force.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: It was a real miracle that on that day he escaped from the doom intended
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: for him.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: John de Witt derived no advantage from his ready compliance with the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: wishes of his fellow citizens. Only a few days after, an attempt
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: was made to stab him, in which he was severely although not mortally
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: wounded.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: This by no means suited the views of the Orange faction. The life of
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: the two brothers being a constant obstacle to their plans, they changed
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: their tactics, and tried to obtain by calumny what they had not been
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: able to effect by the aid of the poniard.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: How rarely does it happen that, in the right moment, a great man is
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: found to head the execution of vast and noble designs; and for that
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: reason, when such a providential concurrence of circumstances does
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: occur, history is prompt to record the name of the chosen one, and to
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: hold him up to the admiration of posterity. But when Satan interposes
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: in human affairs to cast a shadow upon some happy existence, or to
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: overthrow a kingdom, it seldom happens that he does not find at his side
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: some miserable tool, in whose ear he has but to whisper a word to set
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: him at once about his task.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: The wretched tool who was at hand to be the agent of this dastardly
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: plot was one Tyckelaer whom we have already mentioned, a surgeon by
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: profession.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: He lodged an information against Cornelius de Witt, setting forth that
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: the warden--who, as he had shown by the letters added to his signature,
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: was fuming at the repeal of the Perpetual Edict--had, from hatred
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: against William of Orange, hired an assassin to deliver the new Republic
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: of its new Stadtholder; and he, Tyckelaer was the person thus chosen;
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: but that, horrified at the bare idea of the act which he was asked to
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: perpetrate, he had preferred rather to reveal the crime than to commit
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: it.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: This disclosure was, indeed, well calculated to call forth a furious
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: outbreak among the Orange faction. The Attorney General caused, on the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: 16th of August, 1672, Cornelius de Witt to be arrested; and the noble
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: brother of John de Witt had, like the vilest criminal, to undergo, in
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: one of the apartments of the town prison, the preparatory degrees of
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: torture, by means of which his judges expected to force from him the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: confession of his alleged plot against William of Orange.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: But Cornelius was not only possessed of a great mind, but also of a
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: great heart. He belonged to that race of martyrs who, indissolubly
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: wedded to their political convictions as their ancestors were to their
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: faith, are able to smile on pain: while being stretched on the rack, he
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: recited with a firm voice, and scanning the lines according to measure,
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: the first strophe of the "Justum ac tenacem" of Horace, and, making no
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: confession, tired not only the strength, but even the fanaticism, of his
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: executioners.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: The judges, notwithstanding, acquitted Tyckelaer from every charge; at
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: the same time sentencing Cornelius to be deposed from all his offices
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: and dignities; to pay all the costs of the trial; and to be banished
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: from the soil of the Republic for ever.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: This judgment against not only an innocent, but also a great man,
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: was indeed some gratification to the passions of the people, to whose
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: interests Cornelius de Witt had always devoted himself: but, as we shall
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: soon see, it was not enough.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: The Athenians, who indeed have left behind them a pretty tolerable
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: reputation for ingratitude, have in this respect to yield precedence to
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: the Dutch. They, at least in the case of Aristides, contented themselves
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: with banishing him.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: John de Witt, at the first intimation of the charge brought against his
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: brother, had resigned his office of Grand Pensionary. He too received
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: a noble recompense for his devotedness to the best interests of his
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: country, taking with him into the retirement of private life the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: hatred of a host of enemies, and the fresh scars of wounds inflicted by
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: assassins, only too often the sole guerdon obtained by honest people,
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: who are guilty of having worked for their country, and of having
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: forgotten their own private interests.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: In the meanwhile William of Orange urged on the course of events by
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: every means in his power, eagerly waiting for the time when the people,
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: by whom he was idolised, should have made of the bodies of the brothers
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: the two steps over which he might ascend to the chair of Stadtholder.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Thus, then, on the 20th of August, 1672, as we have already stated in
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: the beginning of this chapter, the whole town was crowding towards the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Buytenhof, to witness the departure of Cornelius de Witt from prison,
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: as he was going to exile; and to see what traces the torture of the rack
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: had left on the noble frame of the man who knew his Horace so well.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Yet all this multitude was not crowding to the Buytenhof with the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: innocent view of merely feasting their eyes with the spectacle; there
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: were many who went there to play an active part in it, and to take upon
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: themselves an office which they conceived had been badly filled,--that
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: of the executioner.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: There were, indeed, others with less hostile intentions. All that they
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: cared for was the spectacle, always so attractive to the mob, whose
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: instinctive pride is flattered by it,--the sight of greatness hurled
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: down into the dust.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Has not," they would say, "this Cornelius de Witt been locked up and
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: broken by the rack? Shall we not see him pale, streaming with blood,
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: covered with shame?" And was not this a sweet triumph for the burghers
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: of the Hague, whose envy even beat that of the common rabble; a triumph
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: in which every honest citizen and townsman might be expected to share?
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Moreover," hinted the Orange agitators interspersed through the crowd,
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: whom they hoped to manage like a sharp-edged and at the same time
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: crushing instrument,--"moreover, will there not, from the Buytenhof to
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: the gate of the town, a nice little opportunity present itself to throw
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: some handfuls of dirt, or a few stones, at this Cornelius de Witt, who
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: not only conferred the dignity of Stadtholder on the Prince of Orange
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: merely vi coactus, but who also intended to have him assassinated?"
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Besides which," the fierce enemies of France chimed in, "if the work
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: were done well and bravely at the Hague, Cornelius would certainly not
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: be allowed to go into exile, where he will renew his intrigues with
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: France, and live with his big scoundrel of a brother, John, on the gold
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: of the Marquis de Louvois."
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Being in such a temper, people generally will run rather than walk;
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: which was the reason why the inhabitants of the Hague were hurrying so
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: fast towards the Buytenhof.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Honest Tyckelaer, with a heart full of spite and malice, and with no
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: particular plan settled in his mind, was one of the foremost, being
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: paraded about by the Orange party like a hero of probity, national
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: honour, and Christian charity.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: This daring miscreant detailed, with all the embellishments and
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: flourishes suggested by his base mind and his ruffianly imagination, the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: attempts which he pretended Cornelius de Witt had made to corrupt him;
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: the sums of money which were promised, and all the diabolical stratagems
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: planned beforehand to smooth for him, Tyckelaer, all the difficulties in
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: the path of murder.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: And every phase of his speech, eagerly listened to by the populace,
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: called forth enthusiastic cheers for the Prince of Orange, and groans
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: and imprecations of blind fury against the brothers De Witt.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: The mob even began to vent its rage by inveighing against the iniquitous
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: judges, who had allowed such a detestable criminal as the villain
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Cornelius to get off so cheaply.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Some of the agitators whispered, "He will be off, he will escape from
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: us!"
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Others replied, "A vessel is waiting for him at Schevening, a French
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: craft. Tyckelaer has seen her."
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Honest Tyckelaer! Hurrah for Tyckelaer!" the mob cried in chorus.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "And let us not forget," a voice exclaimed from the crowd, "that at the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: same time with Cornelius his brother John, who is as rascally a traitor
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: as himself, will likewise make his escape."
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "And the two rogues will in France make merry with our money, with the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: money for our vessels, our arsenals, and our dockyards, which they have
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: sold to Louis XIV."
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Well, then, don't let us allow them to depart!" advised one of the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: patriots who had gained the start of the others.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Forward to the prison, to the prison!" echoed the crowd.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Amid these cries, the citizens ran along faster and faster, cocking
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: their muskets, brandishing their hatchets, and looking death and
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: defiance in all directions.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: No violence, however, had as yet been committed; and the file of
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: horsemen who were guarding the approaches of the Buytenhof remained
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: cool, unmoved, silent, much more threatening in their impassibility than
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: all this crowd of burghers, with their cries, their agitation, and their
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: threats. The men on their horses, indeed, stood like so many statues,
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: under the eye of their chief, Count Tilly, the captain of the mounted
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: troops of the Hague, who had his sword drawn, but held it with its point
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: downwards, in a line with the straps of his stirrup.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: This troop, the only defence of the prison, overawed by its firm
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: attitude not only the disorderly riotous mass of the populace, but also
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: the detachment of the burgher guard, which, being placed opposite the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Buytenhof to support the soldiers in keeping order, gave to the rioters
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: the example of seditious cries, shouting,--
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Hurrah for Orange! Down with the traitors!"
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: The presence of Tilly and his horsemen, indeed, exercised a salutary
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: check on these civic warriors; but by degrees they waxed more and more

text: Chapter 2. The Two Brothers
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip

text: "Gentlemen," he said, "uncock your muskets, one of them may go off by

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

text: whom we should have killed would not, for all that, be less dead."

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

text: "Alas!" he thought, "I have deserved all this. She will come no more,

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip

text: prisoner.

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

text: him.

title: The Black Tulip

author: Dumas, Alexandre

author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Van Baerle passed the night in an agony of despair. On the following
title: The Black Tulip

author: Dumas, Alexandre

author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Although these few words of Rosa's somewhat soothed the grief of
title: The Black Tulip

author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip

author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

text: On the following evening, at the usual hour, Van Baerle heard some one
title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

text: body.

title: The Black Tulip

text: to health."

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: He had thought of an attempt to escape, a thing which never entered his

text: head whilst he could see Rosa every day; but the more he thought of it,
title: The Black Tulip

text: the more clearly he saw the impracticability of such an attempt. He was
title: The Black Tulip

text: one of those choice spirits who abhor everything that is common, and who
title: The Black Tulip

text: often lose a good chance through not taking the way of the vulgar, that
title: The Black Tulip

text: high road of mediocrity which leads to everything.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "How is it possible," said Cornelius to himself, "that I should escape
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: from Loewestein, as Grotius has done the same thing before me? Has not
title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: not one fact which takes away all my spirit, I mean Rosa's absence? But
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip

text: my bars, or in braiding cords to let myself down from the window, or
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: in sticking wings on my shoulders to fly, like Daedalus? But luck is
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

text: among the curiosities of Holland.

author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

text: self-respect, or to my love, or even threaten my personal safety. I
title: The Black Tulip

text: don't know how it is, but since my imprisonment I feel a strange and
title: The Black Tulip

text: almost irresistible pugnacity. Well, I shall get at the throat of that
title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

text: window.

author: Dumas, Alexandre

author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: There is nothing more galling to angry people than the coolness of those
title: The Black Tulip

text: on whom they wish to vent their spleen.

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

text: not to have at least a nice little row.

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip

author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: He struck his stick on the stone pavement of the cell, and called out,--
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Halloa! my warbling gentleman, don't you hear me?"
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Men defile us and kill us while loving us, We hang to the earth by a
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: thread; This thread is our root, that is to say, our life, But we raise
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: on high our arms towards heaven."

author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip

text: roared Gryphus.

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "For heaven is our home, Our true home, as from thence comes our soul,
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: As thither our soul returns,--Our soul, that is to say, our perfume."
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Gryphus went up to the prisoner and said,--
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "But you don't see that I have taken means to get you under, and to
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: force you to confess your crimes."
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Are you mad, my dear Master Gryphus?" asked Cornelius.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: And, as he now for the first time observed the frenzied features, the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: flashing eyes, and foaming mouth of the old jailer, he said,--
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Bless the man, he is more than mad, he is furious."
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Gryphus flourished his stick above his head, but Van Baerle moved not,
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: and remained standing with his arms akimbo.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "It seems your intention to threaten me, Master Gryphus."
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Yes, indeed, I threaten you," cried the jailer.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "And with what?"
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "First of all, look at what I have in my hand."
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "I think that's a stick," said Cornelius calmly, "but I don't suppose
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: you will threaten me with that."
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Oh, you don't suppose! why not?"
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Because any jailer who strikes a prisoner is liable to two
title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Yes, who lays hands," said Gryphus, mad with rage, "but there is not a
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: regulation, but which is to be found elsewhere:--
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "'Whosoever takes up the stick will be thrashed by the stick.'"
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Gryphus, growing more and more exasperated by the calm and sententious
title: The Black Tulip

text: tone of Cornelius, brandished his cudgel, but at the moment when he
title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

text: it under his own arm.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Gryphus fairly bellowed with rage.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Hush, hush, my good man," said Cornelius, "don't do anything to lose
title: The Black Tulip

text: your place."

author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Ah, you sorcerer! I'll pinch you worse," roared Gryphus.

author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Yes, I see it, and I am glad of it."
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "You know that it is not generally so when I come upstairs in the
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: morning."

author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "It's true, you generally bring me the worst soup, and the most
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: miserable rations one can imagine. But that's not a punishment to me; I
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: eat only bread, and the worse the bread is to your taste, the better it
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: is to mine."

author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "How so?"
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Oh, it's a very simple thing."

author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Well, tell it me," said Gryphus.
title: The Black Tulip

text: "Very willingly. I know that in giving me bad bread you think you do me
title: The Black Tulip

text: harm."
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Certainly; I don't give it you to please you, you brigand."
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Well, then, I, who am a sorcerer, as you know, change your bad into
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: excellent bread, which I relish more than the best cake; and then I have
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: the double pleasure of eating something that gratifies my palate, and of
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: doing something that puts you in a rage."
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Gryphus answered with a growl.

author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip

text: "Indeed, I am one. I don't say it before all the world, because they
title: The Black Tulip

text: might burn me for it, but as we are alone, I don't mind telling you."
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Well, well, well," answered Gryphus. "But if a sorcerer can change
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: all?"

title: The Black Tulip

text: how it will be after eight days."
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "And," continued Gryphus, "we'll begin this very day. As you are such a
title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

text: inspired him.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Well," Gryphus went on, in his jeering way, "as you are a sorcerer, you
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: will live, notwithstanding."
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Cornelius put on a smiling face again, and said,--
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Have you not seen me make the pigeons come here from Dort?"

text: "Well, a pigeon is a very dainty morsel, and a man who eats one every

text: day would not starve, I think."

author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "And how about the fire?" said Gryphus.

author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Fire! but you know that I'm in league with the devil. Do you think the
title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "A man, however healthy his appetite may be, would not eat a pigeon
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: every day. Wagers have been laid to do so, and those who made them gave

text: "Well, but when I am tired of pigeons, I shall make the fish of the Waal

text: and of the Meuse come up to me."

author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Gryphus opened his large eyes, quite bewildered.

author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "I am rather fond of fish," continued Cornelius; "you never let me have
title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

text: with fish."
title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: and said, putting his hand in his pocket,--

text: Chapter 29. In which Van Baerle, before leaving Loewestein, settles
title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: The two remained silent for some minutes, Gryphus on the offensive, and
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Van Baerle on the defensive.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: Then, as the situation might be prolonged to an indefinite length,
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: fiercely exasperated his jailer, spoke first by putting the question,--
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Well, what do you want, after all?"
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "I'll tell you what I want," answered Gryphus; "I want you to restore to
title: The Black Tulip

text: me my daughter Rosa."
title: The Black Tulip

text: "Your daughter?" cried Van Baerle.
title: The Black Tulip

text: "Yes, my daughter Rosa, whom you have taken from me by your devilish
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: magic. Now, will you tell me where she is?"
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: And the attitude of Gryphus became more and more threatening.
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Rosa is not at Loewestein?" cried Cornelius.

author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "You know well she is not. Once more, will you restore her to me?"
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "I see," said Cornelius, "this is a trap you are laying for me."

author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Now, for the last time, will you tell me where my daughter is?"

author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Guess it, you rogue, if you don't know it."

author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: "Only wait, only wait," growled Gryphus, white with rage, and with
title: The Black Tulip
author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: quivering lips, as his brain began to turn. "Ah, you will not tell me

author: Dumas, Alexandre

text: anything? Well, I'll unlock your teeth!"

title: The Black Tulip

text: which he held in his hands,--

title: The Black Tulip

title: The Black Tulip

text: and as, although out of the reach of his weapon, yet, as long as it
